questions.text: Which is the process designed to prevent microorganisms from reaching a protected environment?
questions.solution:
Asepsis is the process designed to prevent microorganisms from reaching a protected environment.

Sterilization is a process of killing or removal of all living microorganisms either in the vegetative or spore state from an area or surface or a medium.

Decontamination is the process of rendering an article or area free of contaminants, including microbial, chemical, radioactive and other hazardous materials.

Disinfection is the process by which the destruction of microorganisms is achieved with the use of physical or chemical agents. Microbial forms like spores and some viruses may be resistant to certain disinfectants.

questions.text: All of the following are methods of dry heat sterilisation except:
questions.solution:
Autoclaving is a method of moist heat sterilization. 

Dry heat sterilization

Moist heat sterilization

Flaming

Incineration

Hot air oven

Boiling

Pasteurization

Autoclaving

questions.text: What is the temperature that has to be maintained for sterilization in the device shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a sterilizing hot air oven. The temperature to be maintained is 160° C for 2 hours.

Exposure to dry heat in a sterilizing hot air oven ensures the carbonization of organic material and the destruction of microorganisms and spores. The following combinations of temperature and duration of sterilization can be applied in hot air ovens:

  • 180°C for 30 mins
  • 170°C for 60 mins
  • 160⁰C for 2 hours

Related Pearl: Temperatures in Sterilization and Disinfection

Method

Temperature (degree Celsius)

Usual Duration

Hot air oven

160

2 hours

Classic autoclave

121

10–15 minutes

Flash autoclave

134

3 minutes

Ethylene oxide

50 to 60

 1 - 6 hours

Pasteurization Vegetative bacteria Beverages, plastic hospital equipment

3. Radiation

Alcohol Vegetative bacteria, viruses some spores Skin disinfection, hand washing
Hydrogen peroxide Viruses, vegetative bacteria, spores and fungi High-level disinfectant, antiseptic for wounds and discharging ulcers
Chlorine Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi To disinfect water
Iodophors Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi, lethal to spore-bearing organisms Skin disinfection, disinfect blood culture bottles and medical equipment
Crude phenol Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but only slowly effective against spores and acid-fast bacteria. Disinfection of faeces, mopping floors and cleaning drains.
5. Glutaraldehyde   All Endoscopes, bronchoscopes
6. Quarternary ammonium compounds Most bacteria, fungi, lipophilic viruses  General cleaning

questions.text: An OT technician is sterilizing surgical instruments in the following device. What temperature should be maintained?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an autoclave. Surgical instruments are sterilized at 121° C for 10-15 minutes.

Autoclaving is a form of moist heat sterilization which creates an increased temperature of steam under pressure. This method of sterilization is effective against spores also. Autoclaving is done for instruments that cannot withstand high temperatures of hot air oven or dry heat.

questions.text:
Which of the following materials are sterilized by a hot air oven?
  1. Glasswares
  2. Oils and powders
  3. Surgical instruments
  4. Culture media
  5. Swabs and dressings
questions.solution:
Glasswares, oils and powders, swabs, and dressings are sterilized by a hot air oven.

Surgical instruments and culture media are sterilized by autoclave.

questions.text: You have performed an upper GI endoscopy on a HbsAg positive patient. Which of the following should be used to sterilize the scope?
questions.solution:
2% glutaraldehyde is used to sterilize endoscopes and fibreoptic scopes.

Aldehydes in 2% solutions (like glutaraldehyde and formaldehyde) have sporicidal activities. 

Glutaraldehyde is usually efficacious against tubercle bacteria, fungi & viruses.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the use of ethylene oxide in sterilisation and disinfection?

choices.text: It is an inflammable and explosive gas
It is used for heat-sensitive objects
It is mixed with nitrogen for sterilization

questions.solution:
A mixture of ethylene oxide with carbon dioxide is used for sterilization, not with nitrogen. 

Ethylene oxide is an alkylating agent and has inflammable and explosive properties. It is often mixed with the following prior to use:

  • Carbon dioxide - decreases its explosive nature
  • Water vapor - increases the efficiency of the gas

Sterilization using this gas is usually done at 50-60 °C. and is suitable for heat-sensitive items like plastics, heart valves, dental equipment. It is effective against bacteria, spores, and some viruses.

questions.text: The following machine was used during a cardiac bypass surgery. How is it best sterilized?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a heart-lung machine. It is best sterilized using ethylene oxide.

Ethylene oxide gas diffuses through many types of porous materials and readily penetrates some plastics and is used for sterilizing machines.

questions.text: Povidone - iodine is an example of:
questions.solution:
Povidone - iodine is an iodophor.

Iodophors are iodine-based disinfectants in which iodine is combined with solubilizing agents or carriers. This results in the formation of a complex that provides a sustained release reservoir of iodine and releases small amounts of free iodine in an aqueous solution.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of precurrent disinfection?

choices.text: Chlorination of a well by village public health authorities
Disinfection of kidney tray used during delivery of placenta
Disinfection of bed linen after the death of a patient
Disinfection of artery forceps following a surgery

questions.solution:
Chlorination of water in a well is an example of precurrent disinfection. 

Precurrent disinfection refers to prophylactic disinfection prior to discharge of infectious material. This includes pasteurization of milk, chlorination of water and hand washing.

Concurrent disinfection is the application of disinfection methods after discharge of infectious material from a person or soiling. This includes disinfection of urine, faeces, vomit, contaminated linen, clothes, hands.

Terminal disinfection is done after the death of a patient or transfer or after cessation of isolation.

questions.text: Chlorine is the main disinfectant element in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Cetrimide (trade name - Cetavlon) is a quaternary ammonia compound (QAC) that does not contain chlorine. QACs are low-level disinfectants and are sporostatic but not sporicidal. It is a bactericidal agent against vegetative gram-positive organisms.

Other QACs include cetrimide (cetavlon) and benzalkonium chloride.

Savlon contains cetrimide and chlorhexidine and is mainly used for plastic items. Clinical thermometers may be best disinfected in Savlon mixed with spirit in a 1:6 ratio.

Chlorine compounds are potent disinfectants that are bactericidal, fungicidal, sporicidal, tuberculocidal, and virucidal.

Chlorine compounds Mechanism of action and uses
1. Bleaching powder (chlorinated lime) Disinfection of water, feces, and urine
2. Chloramine - T Has a prolonged bactericidal effect, used in a health care setting
3. Hypochlorites Disinfect infectious waste and surfaces
4. Halazone tablets Disinfect small quantities of water
5. Superoxidized water Saline is electrolyzed to release hypochlorous acid and chlorine, which act as disinfectants

questions.text: Hydrogen peroxide is:
questions.solution:
Hydrogen peroxide is effective against bacteria, fungi, spores and viruses.

It is used in the hospital setting to disinfect surfaces. Sporicidal activities require higher concentrations and longer contact times. A 3% solution is also used as an antiseptic and for cleaning wounds and discharging ulcers.

questions.text: Which among the following is a low-level disinfectant?
questions.solution:
Benzalkonium chloride is a quaternary ammonium compound that is used as a low-level disinfectant.

There are 3 types of disinfectants:

  • Low-level disinfectant - kills only vegetative bacteria, fungi and lipid enveloped viruses (e.g. quaternary ammonium compounds)
  • Intermediate level disinfectant: kills all microbes including mycobacteria and non-enveloped viruses, but not spores (e.g. alcohol, iodophors)
  • High-level disinfectant - This is a chemical that kills all microbial pathogens and some spores if the contact time is increased (e.g. glutaraldehyde, hydrogen peroxide)

questions.text: Which among the following is not a sporicidal agent?
questions.solution:
Cresol a phenolic compound is not sporicidal.

Disinfectants that are not sporicidal are:

  • Biguanides
  • Alcohols
  • Heavy metal disinfectants
  • Organic acids
  • QACs
  • Phenolic compounds

Sporicidal disinfectants include:

  • Aldehydes
  • Chlorine disinfectants
  • Hydrogen peroxide
  • Ethylene oxide
  • Peracetic acids

questions.text: Which of the following disinfectants has anti-viral action?
questions.solution:
Hypochlorite is an antiviral disinfectant.

Antiviral disinfectants include:

  • Chlorine compounds 
  • Phenol (at high concentrations)
  • Aldehydes
  • Hydrogen peroxide

questions.text: A nurse in a PHC is using bleaching powder to disinfect bed linen contaminated with stool. What is the amount that she should use?
questions.solution:
Bleaching powder of 50 g/L of water is required for disinfecting feces and urine.

The agents commonly used for disinfecting faeces and urine are:

Disinfectant

Amount per litre

Per cent

Bleaching powder

50 g

5

Crude phenol

100 ml

10

Cresol

50 ml

5

Formalin

100 ml

10

questions.text: Which of the following methods of disinfection is not effective against prions?
questions.solution:
Benzalkonium chloride is not effective against prions.

Prions can be inactivated by following the given steps:

  • Immersing the instruments in 1N NaOH or sodium hypochlorite for 1 hour
  • Then they are transferred to water
  • Then they are heated in a gravity displacement autoclave at 121°C for 1 hour
  • After this, they are cleaned and subjected to routine sterilization

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not effective for disinfection of sputum of patients?
questions.solution:
Chlorhexidine is not used to disinfect sputum.

Sputum can be disinfected by:

  • Autoclaving or boiling - if a considerable amount of sputum is present (e.g. in TB hospitals)
  • 5% cresol - patients are asked to spit in a sputum cup half-filled with cresol
  • Burning - for samples received in gauze or paper handkerchiefs

questions.text:
Match the following.
Biological indicators of efficiency    

Sterilization methods
1. Clostridium tetani a. Ethylene oxide
2. Geobacillus stearothermophilus    b. Ionizing radiation
3. Bacillus atrophaeus c. Autoclave
4. Bacillus pumilus d. Hot air oven
questions.solution:
The biological indicators used to check the efficiency of various sterilization methods are:

  • Clostridium tetani - Hot air oven
  • Geobacillus stearothermophilus - Autoclave
  • Bacillus atrophaeus - Ethylene oxide
  • Bacillus pumilus - Ionizing radiation
Sterilization technique Bacteria
Hot air oven

Spores of Bacillus subtilis subsp. Niger (reclassified as B.atrophaeus)

Clostridium tetani 
Autoclave Geobacillus stearothermophilus
Filtration

Serratia marscesens

Brevundimonas diminuta
Ionizing radiation Bacillus pumilus
Ethylene oxide Bacillus globigii (reclassified as B.atrophaeus)
Plasma sterilization

Geobacillus stearothermophilus

Bacillus atrophaeus (Bacillus subtilis subsp. Niger)

questions.text: Rideal-Walker co-efficient is employed for the assessment of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The Rideal-Walker coefficient helps in assessing the power of a disinfectant relative to phenol.

It assesses this by determining the phenol coefficient (PC). A PC value of > 1 indicates that it is more effective than phenol. The higher the number, the greater its effectiveness in comparison to phenol and vice versa. Traditional organisms used to test the power of the disinfectant include S. aureus and Salmonella enteric subtype typhi.

Phenol coefficient = The dilution of test disinfectant which kills microorganisms in a given time ÷ The dilution of phenol which kills the microorganism in the same time under identical conditions.

Other tests that are used for disinfectants are as follows:

  • Chick Martin test - modification of the Rideal-Walker test where disinfectants act in the presence of organic matter like feces or yeast to simulate natural conditions
  • Kelsey-Skyes test (capacity test) - tests the capacity of a disinfectant to retain its activity when used repeatedly.
  • In-use test - determines whether the chosen disinfectant is effective in actual hospital use

Joseph Lister first introduced phenol (carbolic acid) as an antiseptic to sterilize surgical instruments and  clean wounds. Lister's work led to a reduction in postoperative infections and made surgery safer for patients, distinguishing him as the 'Father of Modern Surgery' and 'Father of Antiseptic Surgery'.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the Spaulding classification?

choices.text: Semi-critical items require high level disinfection
Non-critical items do not require disinfection
Cardiac catheters are classified as critical items
Critical items are associated with a high risk of infection

questions.solution:
Under the Spaulding classification, non-critical items require intermediate or low-level disinfection.

Related Pearl: The Spaulding Classification

The Spaulding classification classifies medical devices according to the degree of risk of infection if they are contaminated.

Device

Description

Examples

Disinfection

Non-critical device

Lower risk of infection as the device comes in contact with intact or normal skin.

Stethoscope, walls, furniture, BP cuff, etc.

Intermediate/low-level disinfectant.

Clean, dry and store for future use.

Semi-critical devices

Lower risk of infection as these devices come in contact with mucosa and do not penetrate into sterile areas of the body.

Fiber-optic endoscopes, laryngoscopes, bronchoscopes, cystoscopes, vaginal specula, etc.

High-level disinfectant to be used after proper cleaning or sterilization by heat.

Critical devices

High risks of infection as these devices come in contact with sterile areas of the body like blood.

Needles, cardiac catheters, implants, intrauterine devices, urinary catheters, etc.

High-level disinfectant is indicated with sterilization with heat, ethylene oxide, etc.

questions.text: While collecting blood for samples, you have spilled some on the floor. What would be the immediate next step?

choices.text: Call the infection control team of the hospital

questions.solution:
The immediate next step in this scenario is to clean the spilled blood with absorbable material.

This absorbable material is then discarded in the yellow bin. Following this, sodium hypochlorite solution is used to decontaminate the surface. The concentrations of sodium hypochlorite used are: 

  • < 10 mL blood spill - 1:100 dilution to decontaminate non-porous surfaces
  • > 10 mL blood spill or culture spill - 1:10 dilution for the first application, followed by 1:100 dilution

questions.text: A blood spill in the operation theatre must be cleaned with _____.
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. It is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labelled containment. 

A 1:10–1:100 dilution of 5.25%–6.15% sodium hypochlorite (i.e., household bleach) or an EPA-registered tuberculocidal disinfectant has been recommended for decontaminating blood spills. 

Related Pearl: Methods of sterilisation

Method of disinfection or sterilisation Material

Hot air oven Glasswares, scalpels, forceps, cutting instruments, test tubes

Autoclave Culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut
Isopropyl alcohol Clinical thermometers, stethoscopes, probes

Beta propiolactone/

Plasma sterilisation Arthroscopes, urethroscopes
Ethylene oxide Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments, sutures, books, clothings
Filtration (Seitz filters) Bacterial vaccines, intravenous solutions
5% cresol, hot air oven Sharp instruments

Ionising radiation

(Cold air sterilization)

 Catgut, swabs, plastic, syringes, needles, gloves, catheters, grafts
Chlorhexidine Disinfecting surgeon’s hands prior to surgery
Iodophor Disinfecting surgical site prior to surgery
70% ethanol Disinfectant skin prior to venepuncture or immunisation
Thiomersal Preservative in vaccine
Silver sulfadiazine Cleanse burn wounds
Hypochlorite Cleanup of blood spill from a patient with hepatitis B or C
